Chamada de Palestras - 10º Fórum Brasileiro de CSIRTs

[URL_c39c68d110]

Convidamos todos os profissionais atuantes em [ORGANIZATION_4107c7b1d6] (CSIRTs) ou que trabalhem com segurança e
   tratamento de incidentes no seu dia a dia, a submeter propostas de
   palestras de interesse da [ORGANIZATION_8f97e89543] no
   Brasil, para o 10º Fórum Brasileiro de CSIRTs, que ocorrerá nos dias 19
   e 20 de setembro de 2022, no [LOCATION_b1e1dde627] Morumbi, em[LOCATION_a505dbb38a] Paulo/SP.

Para cada proposta aceita, o [ORGANIZATION_9634d99a56] proverá apoio para transporte e
   estadia de um profissional para apresentá-la.

Temas de Interesse

A apresentação deve tratar de aspectos práticos e operacionais das
   atividades de tratamento e gestão de incidentes de segurança, bem como
   de aspectos da segurança da informação ou da Internet que sejam
   relacionados com ou tenham impacto no processo de tratamento de
   incidentes.

Uma lista não exaustiva de temas de interesse para este evento segue:
     * Estudos de caso relacionados a incidentes tratados
     * Automatização de processos de tratamento de incidentes
     * Compartilhamento automatizado de informações sobre ataques e
       ameaças
     * Impactos, para CSIRTs, de novos regulamentos e legislação
     * Tendências observadas nos incidentes tratados
     * Threat hunting como parte do processo de gestão de incidentes
     * Uso de netflows no contexto de segurança e tratamento de incidentes
     * Iniciativas de conscientização sobre segurança
     * Implementação de boas práticas e combate a abusos
     * Detecção e mitigação de ataques DDoS
     * Detecção, mitigação e remediação de códigos maliciosos (RATs,
       ransomware, botnets, etc)
     * Segurança e Internet das Coisas
     * Detecção e mitigação de ataques a aplicações Web
     * Outros temas de interesse para CSIRTs

Importante: é desejável que as apresentações sejam aplicadas e
   práticas, e *não* devem ser voltadas a produtos e soluções de
   fornecedores específicos, com fins comerciais, nem trabalhos que sejam
   com ênfase puramente acadêmica.

Submissão de Propostas

As propostas de palestras deverão ser enviadas para o e-mail
   <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_8b310a00a3]> com os seguintes dados:
     * Título completo.
     * Resumo (Abstract) estendido, rascunho dos slides ou descrição
       detalhada, o importante é que seja possível avaliar o conteúdo e
       abordagem. O comitê avaliador de trabalhos poderá, a seu critério,
       solicitar informações adicionais ou complementares.
     * Nome completo, endereço de e-mail, mini CV e organização a que
       pertence cada um dos autores.

Datas Importantes

* 10 de julho de 2022: Data limite para envio de propostas de
       palestras
     * 15 de julho de 2022: Anúncio das propostas aceitas e publicação da
       agenda
     * 19 e 20 de setembro de 2022: 10º Fórum Brasileiro de CSIRTs
     * 21 de setembro de 2022: Workshop MISP

Atenciosamente,

--
CERT.br/NIC.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>

certbr-anuncios mailing list

Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servidor NTP mal configurado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são servidores NTP mal configurados sob
sua responsabilidade (123/udp). Estes servidores podem ser abusados
para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação de serviço,
consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos
de rede com funcionalidade NTP, como roteadores e CPEs (modem ou
roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* Os servidores NTP listados sejam configurados de modo a corrigir
 este problema.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
servidores NTP mal configurados, por favor repasse essa mensagem para
alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

Os indicadores no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indicam os tipos de
problemas testados e significam:

* monlist: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes são o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

* readvar: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes sao o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

[IP_ADDRESS_f36fd7c474]    | 2716   | OPEN   | 2022-06-06T11:56:56Z | monlist: timeout/0/0, readvar: open/1/400
====================================================================================

Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre configuração segura de
  servidores NTP?

- Guia NTP para Linux/BSD
    [URL_8810d617ed]

Team [ORGANIZATION_af0c3a7b9c] Secure NTP Template (inclui cisco e juniper)
  - [URL_ad8fce50c6]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um servidor NTP vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de servidores NTP
  que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em ataques
  distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS). O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos servidores brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu servidor através dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha]
            ```

            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.

        Your task:
        - Classify the incident below using the most appropriate category code (CAT1 to CAT12).

         Let's first understand the problem and devise a plan to solve the problem. Then, let's carry out the plan and solve the problem step by step.
response:
### **Category:** CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation  
### **Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **misconfigured NTP server** that allows commands like `monlist` or `readvar`, which can generate **large responses** to forged requests. This configuration flaw is a **technical vulnerability** that could be exploited to amplify traffic and launch **DDoS attacks** (as described in the alert). While the actual DDoS attack may not have occurred yet, the **potential for exploitation** of this vulnerability aligns with **CAT5**, which focuses on **using technical flaws** (e.g., misconfigurations, unpatched systems) to enable attacks.  

### **Rationale:**  
- **Key Issue:** The server is vulnerable due to improper configuration, not an active attack.  
- **NIST Alignment:**  
  - **CAT5** explicitly covers exploitation of technical flaws (e.g., misconfigured services, unpatched systems) that could lead to attacks.  
  - **CAT3** (Denial of Service Attack) would apply if the attack had already occurred (e.g., active DDoS), but this incident is about the **potential for exploitation**, not the attack itself.  
- **Examples from NIST:** The description mirrors **CAT5** examples like "exploitation of critical CVE" or "misconfigured services" (e.g., NTP amplification).  

### **Conclusion:**  
The incident is best classified under **CAT5** because it highlights a **technical vulnerability** (misconfigured NTP) that could be exploited to enable **DDoS attacks**, aligning with the definition of **Vulnerability Exploitation**.

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são servidores NTP mal configurados sob

para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação de serviço,
consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos
de rede com funcionalidade NTP, como roteadores e CPEs (modem ou
roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* Os servidores NTP listados sejam configurados de modo a corrigir
 este problema.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
servidores NTP mal configurados, por favor repasse essa mensagem para
alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

Os indicadores no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indicam os tipos de
problemas testados e significam:

* monlist: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes são o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

* readvar: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes sao o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_f36fd7c474]    | 2716   | OPEN   | 2022-06-06T11:56:56Z | monlist: timeout/0/0, readvar: open/1/400
====================================================================================

Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre configuração segura de
  servidores NTP?

- Guia NTP para Linux/BSD
    [URL_8810d617ed]

Team [ORGANIZATION_af0c3a7b9c] Secure NTP Template (inclui cisco e juniper)
  - [URL_ad8fce50c6]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um servidor NTP vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de servidores NTP
  que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em ataques
  distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS). O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos servidores brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu servidor através dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha]
            ```

- An IPTV device that is vulnerable to compromise (such as HTV), either directly through the default firmware or through a trojan downloaded app

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. From your side, you would be able to observe the attack as a burst of traffic that likely saturated the network adapter of the source device for perhaps 30 seconds. - **Category Code:** CAT3

The description explicitly states that the compromised host was part of a coordinated attack causing **packet loss and network saturation**, which aligns with the definition of a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. While the host was compromised due to vulnerabilities (e.g., default credentials, unpatched software), the **primary incident** described is the **DDoS attack itself**, not the underlying compromise. The NIST example for CAT3 includes "botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server," which matches this scenario. 

### Key Justification:
- **DDoS Attack:** The incident involves a **large-scale DDoS attack** (10 Gbps) that disrupted services, requiring mitigation via null-route operations.  
- **Botnet Participation:** The compromised host was part of a botnet, which is a common vector for volumetric DoS attacks.  
- **Focus on Impact:** The description emphasizes the **effect of the attack** (packet loss, network saturation) rather than the specific vulnerabilities exploited to compromise the host.  

Other categories (e.g., **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**) might apply to the **root cause** (compromised devices), but the **primary incident** described is the **DDoS attack**, making **CAT3** the most appropriate classification.

* O que é o protocolo CoAP (5683/udp)?

O protocolo Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP) é um protocolo
  para transferência de conteúdo web através do protocolo UDP. Esse
  protocolo é utilizado principalmente por dispositivos com recursos
  limitados de memória.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com o serviço CoAP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a
  requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O CoAP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros, envolvendo sua
  rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de implicar em um consumo
  de banda maior.

  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser encontradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local ou para os 
  IPs que necessitam do acesso a esse serviço.

response:
### **Category:** CAT3: Denial of Service Attack  
### **Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **potential vulnerability in the CoAP (Constrained Application Protocol) service** running on port 5683/UDP. This protocol is susceptible to **amplification-based DDoS attacks**, where attackers exploit the service to generate massive traffic volumes, overwhelming target networks and causing service unavailability. The CERT.br alert highlights that the exposed CoAP service could be **abused for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks**, consuming network resources and impacting third parties.  

While the incident itself is not an active attack, the **risk of exploitation** aligns with **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)**, as the vulnerability directly enables the **potential for volumetric DDoS attacks** (e.g., UDP flood, amplification attacks). The alert emphasizes mitigating this risk by disabling or restricting access to the CoAP service, which is a proactive measure to prevent systems from being used in such attacks.  

### **Key Justification:**  
- **DDoS Risk:** The CoAP service is explicitly linked to **amplification attacks**, a classic DDoS vector.  
- **System Unavailability:** The alert warns of resource consumption and network impact, which are core to **Denial of Service attacks**.  
- **Proactive Mitigation:** The CERT’s request to disable or restrict the service is aimed at **preventing exploitation** of the vulnerability, which falls under **CAT3** (as it addresses the root cause of potential DDoS threats).  

Other categories (e.g., **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**) might seem relevant, but **CAT3** is more precise here because the focus is on the **potential for DDoS attacks** rather than a direct exploit of a technical flaw (e.g., RCE or SQL injection). The alert’s primary goal is to **mitigate DDoS risks**, not to address a specific technical vulnerability.

response:
**Category:** CAT3: Denial of Service Attack  
**Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **potential vulnerability in the CoAP (Constrained Application Protocol) service** running on port 5683/UDP. This protocol is susceptible to **amplification-based DDoS attacks**, where attackers exploit the service to generate massive traffic volumes, overwhelming target networks and causing service unavailability. The CERT.br alert explicitly warns that the exposed CoAP service could be **abused for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks**, consuming network resources and impacting third parties.  

While the incident itself is not an active attack, the **risk of exploitation** aligns with **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)**, as the vulnerability directly enables the **potential for volumetric DDoS attacks** (e.g., UDP flood, amplification attacks). The alert emphasizes mitigating this risk by disabling or restricting access to the CoAP service, which is a proactive measure to prevent systems from being used in such attacks.  

**Key Justification:**  
- **DDoS Risk:** The CoAP service is explicitly linked to **amplification attacks**, a classic DDoS vector.  
- **System Unavailability:** The alert warns of resource consumption and network impact, which are core to **Denial of Service attacks**.  
- **Proactive Mitigation:** The CERT’s request to disable or restrict the service is aimed at **preventing exploitation** of the vulnerability, which falls under **CAT3** (as it addresses the root cause of potential DDoS threats).  

Other categories (e.g., **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**) might seem relevant, but **CAT3** is more precise here because the focus is on the **potential for DDoS attacks** rather than a direct exploit of a technical flaw (e.g., RCE or SQL injection). The alert’s primary goal is to **mitigate DDoS risks**, not to address a specific technical vulnerability.

response:
### **Classification:**  
**CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**  

---

### **Explanation:**  
The incident involves the **exploitation of a technical flaw** (the Apple Remote Management Service, ARMS) that can be leveraged for **DDoS amplification attacks**. The key points that align this incident with **CAT5** are:  

1. **Technical Flaw**:  
   - The ARMS service is inherently vulnerable to **UDP reflection/amplification attacks** due to its design. Attackers can exploit this by sending small requests to amplify responses, overwhelming target networks. This is a **known technical vulnerability** (e.g., CVE-2019-8562), which falls under **Vulnerability Exploitation**.  

2. **Potential for Exploitation**:  
   - The alert highlights that the service is **exposed to the internet** (port 3283/UDP) and can be **abused for DDoS attacks**. This is not an active attack but a **risk of exploitation** due to a misconfigured or exposed service. The focus is on the **exploitation of a critical vulnerability** rather than an ongoing attack.  

3. **NIST Category Alignment**:  
   - **CAT5** explicitly covers "using technical flaws for attacks" (e.g., critical CVEs, RCE, or amplification attacks). The ARMS vulnerability is a **technical flaw** that enables **amplification-based DDoS**, which matches the definition of **CAT5**.  
   - While **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)** could apply if the attack were already occurring, the incident here is a **prevention alert** about a **potential vulnerability exploitation**, not an active attack.  

---

### **Why Not Other Categories?**  
- **CAT3 (DoS Attack)**: This would apply if the DDoS attack were already in progress. Since the alert is about a **potential risk**, not an ongoing attack, **CAT3 is less appropriate**.  
- **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt)**: This category is for unconfirmed attacks (e.g., network scans, brute force). The incident is a **security advisory**, not an unconfirmed intrusion attempt.  

---

### **Conclusion:**  
The incident is best categorized under **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)** because it highlights the **exploitation of a known technical vulnerability** (ARMS) that can be used for **DDoS amplification attacks**. The focus is on the **risk posed by the vulnerability** rather than an active attack.

* O que é o serviço ARMS (3283/udp)?

O serviço ARMS (Apple Remote Management Service) é um serviço executado
  em sistemas MAC OS X que é parte do serviço ARD (Apple Remote Desktop)
  e é habilitado na porta 3283/udp. Esses serviços são utilizados para 
  fornecer acesso remoto e de gerenciamento para esses sistemas.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, o serviço ARMS pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com ARMS retorna uma resposta maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O ARMS pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros, envolvendo sua
  rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de implicar em um consumo
  de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

Recomendamos que desabilite o serviço ARD caso ele nao seja utilizado.

Caso o serviço seja necessário a você ou sua organização, pedimos 
  que execute os procedimentos descritos na URL abaixo para permitir
  o acesso a esses serviços apenas para os endereços IP autorizados.

- ARD/ARMS abuse and securing MacOSX devices against DDoS Amplification attacks

  [URL_4b1152b059]

        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

        Your task:
        - Classify the incident below using the most appropriate category code (CAT1 to CAT12).

         Let's first understand the problem and devise a plan to solve the problem. Then, let's carry out the plan and solve the problem step by step. The category is: CAT5
response:
**Category:** CAT5  
**Explanation:**  

The incident falls under **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation** because it involves the exploitation of a technical flaw in the Apple Remote Management Service (ARMS). Specifically, the ARMS service, when exposed to the public internet via UDP port 3283, is vulnerable to **UDP reflection/amplification attacks**. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to launch **DDoS attacks**, which amplify traffic by leveraging the service's response size, overwhelming target networks and consuming bandwidth.  

The CERT.br alert highlights the **technical flaw** (exposure of ARMS) and its potential misuse for attacks, aligning with CAT5. While the DDoS attack itself might fall under CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack), the primary focus of the incident is the **exploitation of a known vulnerability** (ARMS) rather than the attack's execution. The warning emphasizes mitigating the vulnerability to prevent exploitation, which is the core of CAT5.  

**Key Justification:**  
- **Technical Flaw:** ARMS is a known vulnerability that enables amplification attacks.  
- **Exploitation Risk:** The alert warns about potential misuse of the vulnerability for DDoS, not an active attack.  
- **Mitigation Focus:** The solution centers on patching the vulnerability (disabling ARMS or restricting access), not responding to an ongoing attack.  

Thus, **CAT5** is the most appropriate category.

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são servidores NTP mal configurados sob
sua responsabilidade (123/udp). Estes servidores podem ser abusados
para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação de serviço,
consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos
de rede com funcionalidade NTP, como roteadores e CPEs (modem ou
roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* Os servidores NTP listados sejam configurados de modo a corrigir
 este problema.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
servidores NTP mal configurados, por favor repasse essa mensagem para
alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

Os indicadores no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indicam os tipos de
problemas testados e significam:

* monlist: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes são o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

* readvar: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes sao o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre configuração segura de
  servidores NTP?

- Guia NTP para Linux/BSD
    [URL_8810d617ed]

  - [URL_ad8fce50c6]

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de servidores NTP
  que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em ataques
  distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS). O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos servidores brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

            ```
        
        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

        Your task:
        - Classify the incident below using the most appropriate category code (CAT1 to CAT12).
        - Justify based on the explanation of the selected category.
         Let's first understand the problem and devise a plan to solve the problem. Then, let's carry out the plan and solve the problem step by step.
response:
### **Category**: CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  
### **Explanation**:  
The incident involves a **technical flaw** in the configuration of a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server. Specifically, the server allows commands like `monlist` or `readvar`, which can generate **amplified traffic** (e.g., 400 bytes of response for a 1-byte request). This vulnerability can be exploited to **launch Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks** by leveraging the server’s network resources for malicious purposes.  

The **core issue** is the **exploitation of a known technical flaw** (misconfigured NTP) that could be used to compromise network availability or amplify attacks. While the attack itself (DDoS) is classified under **CAT3**, the **primary focus** of the incident is the **vulnerability exploitation** (misconfigured NTP) that enables such attacks.  

### **Key Justification**:  
- **CAT5** is the most appropriate category because the incident centers on a **technical vulnerability** (misconfigured NTP) that can be exploited for malicious purposes.  
- The **potential for exploitation** (e.g., DDoS amplification) aligns with the definition of **Vulnerability Exploitation** (e.g., "exploitation of critical CVE" in the NIST examples).  
- **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)** would apply if the attack were already underway, but the incident here is a **warning about a potential exploit**, not an active attack.  
- **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources)** is less relevant because the misuse here is **not about unauthorized resource use** (e.g., cryptocurrency mining) but rather **network amplification for DDoS**.  

### **Conclusion**:  
The incident is a **technical vulnerability** that could be exploited to enable DDoS attacks, making **CAT5** the most accurate classification. The email serves as a **notification of the vulnerability** and its potential impact, not an ongoing attack.

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.

response:
**Category:** CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  
**Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **misconfigured NTP server** that allows commands like `monlist` or `readvar`, enabling **amplification attacks** (a type of vulnerability exploitation). These vulnerabilities can be exploited to generate large volumes of traffic for **DDoS attacks**, which fall under **technical flaws** (e.g., misconfigurations, insecure protocols). The core issue is the **exploitation of a technical flaw** (misconfigured NTP) that could be weaponized for malicious purposes, aligning with **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**.  

**Key Justification:**  
- **Technical Flaw:** The misconfiguration of NTP servers (e.g., allowing `monlist`/`readvar`) is a **technical vulnerability** that enables amplification attacks.  
- **Exploitation Risk:** The warning highlights the potential for **exploitation** (e.g., DDoS attacks) via this vulnerability, not an active attack itself.  
- **NIST Alignment:** **CAT5** explicitly covers "use of technical flaws for attacks," such as misconfigurations or insecure protocols, which matches this scenario.  

**Alternative Consideration:**  
While **CAT3** (Denial of Service Attack) could apply if the attack were already underway, the incident here is a **notification about a potential vulnerability**, not an active DDoS. Thus, **CAT5** is more precise as it focuses on the **exploitation of a technical flaw** (the root cause).

response:
### Classification:
**Category:** CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  
**Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **technical flaw** in the configuration of a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server, which allows commands like `monlist` or `readvar` to generate **amplified network traffic**. This vulnerability can be exploited to launch **distributed denial-of-service (DDoS)** attacks by abusing the server's resources for malicious purposes.  

**Key Justification:**  
- **Technical Flaw:** The misconfigured NTP server has a **critical vulnerability** (e.g., allowing amplification attacks) that can be exploited to harm networks or systems.  
- **Exploitation Risk:** The vulnerability directly enables **remote exploitation** to amplify traffic and contribute to DDoS attacks, which aligns with **CAT5** (Vulnerability Exploitation).  
- **No Active Attack:** While the incident does not describe an ongoing attack, the **potential for exploitation** is the core issue, as the vulnerability could be leveraged by attackers.  

**Why Not Other Categories?**  
- **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack):** This category applies to **actual attacks** (e.g., ongoing DDoS), not the **potential exploitation** of a vulnerability.  
- **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources):** This focuses on unauthorized use for purposes like cryptocurrency mining, not the **technical exploitation** of a flaw.  
- **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt):** This applies to unconfirmed attacks, not a **known vulnerability** awaiting exploitation.  

**Conclusion:**  
The incident falls under **CAT5** because it highlights a **technical vulnerability** (misconfigured NTP server) that can be exploited for malicious attacks (e.g., DDoS), fulfilling the definition of **Vulnerability Exploitation**.

        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.

        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.

        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.

        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.

        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.

### Classification:
**Category:** CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  
**Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **technical flaw** in the configuration of a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server, which allows commands like `monlist` or `readvar` to generate **amplified network traffic**. This vulnerability can be exploited to launch **distributed denial-of-service (DDoS)** attacks by abusing the server's resources for malicious purposes.  

**Key Justification:**  
- **Technical Flaw:** The misconfigured NTP server has a **critical vulnerability** (e.g., allowing amplification attacks) that can be exploited to harm networks or systems.  
- **Exploitation Risk:** The vulnerability directly enables **remote exploitation** to amplify traffic and contribute to DDoS attacks, which aligns with **CAT5** (Vulnerability Exploitation).  
- **No Active Attack:** While the incident does not describe an ongoing attack, the **potential for exploitation** is the core issue, as the vulnerability could be leveraged by attackers.  

**Why Not Other Categories?**  
- **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack):** This category applies to **actual attacks** (e.g., ongoing DDoS), not the **potential exploitation** of a vulnerability.  
- **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources):** This focuses on unauthorized use for purposes like cryptocurrency mining, not the **technical exploitation** of a flaw.  
- **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt):** This applies to unconfirmed attacks, not a **known vulnerability** awaiting exploitation.  

**Conclusion:**  
The incident falls under **CAT5** because it highlights a **technical vulnerability** (misconfigured NTP server) that can be exploited for malicious attacks (e.g., DDoS), fulfilling the definition of **Vulnerability Exploitation**. The category is: CAT5

        Explanation: Unknown
        
        OUTPUT:
        Category: [NIST code]
        Explanation: [Justification for the chosen category]

prompt:

Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
   equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_b10af8b264]  | 2716   | OPEN   | 2022-09-09T11:17:54Z | snmp: open/1/95
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testado]
            ```

        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.

        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.

        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.

        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

response:
### **Classification:**
- **Category Code:** CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)  
- **Explanation:**  
  The incident involves the **misconfiguration of the SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol)** service, which can be exploited to enable **UDP-based amplification attacks**. These attacks are a type of **volumetric DDoS** where an attacker forges the victim's IP address and leverages the SNMP service to amplify traffic, overwhelming target systems and consuming network bandwidth.  

  While the incident does not describe an **active attack** (e.g., ongoing network flooding), the **vulnerability itself is a known method for launching DDoS attacks** (e.g., Mirai botnets). The CERT.br notification highlights the **potential risk of the service being abused** to participate in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) campaigns, which aligns with **CAT3** (Denial of Service Attack) as it directly relates to the **technical mechanism** used to disrupt services.  

  **Why not other categories?**  
  - **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)**: While the SNMP misconfiguration is a technical flaw, the classification focuses on the **consequence** (DDoS) rather than the flaw itself.  
  - **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt)**: This category applies to unconfirmed attacks (e.g., network scans), but the incident is a **proactive warning** about a **potential exploit** (not an ongoing attempt).  
  - **CAT3** is the most appropriate because it directly addresses the **risk of service disruption** via amplification attacks, which are explicitly listed in the NIST examples (e.g., "UDP flood").  

### **Conclusion:**  
The incident is categorized under **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)** because the SNMP misconfiguration poses a **clear risk of enabling DDoS attacks**, which are a core component of this category. The focus is on the **potential for service disruption** via network amplification, not the actual execution of an attack.

We manually reviewed the captures from this attack and do not believe that your IP address was spoofed, based on the limited number of distinct hosts attacking us, the identicality of many attacking IP addresses to ones we've seen in the past, and the non-random distribution of IP addresses.

It is possible that this host is one of the following, from the responses that others have sent us:

- A compromised router, such as a [ORGANIZATION_4fa360a1dd] that is running with WAN access enabled; a [ORGANIZATION_9954db40ae] which still allows a default admin username and password; a Netis, with a built-in internet-accessible backdoor ([URL_2764a7b048]); or one running an old AirOS version with a vulnerable and exposed administrative interface

- A compromised DVR, such as a "Hikvision" brand device (ref: [URL_4d5849d65d])

- A compromised Xerox-branded device
- Some other compromised standalone device
- A server with an insecure password that was brute-forced, such as through SSH or RDP
- A server running an improperly secured Hadoop installation
- A server running a pre-13.10.3 GitLab instance that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-22205
- A compromised [ORGANIZATION_c7bac46904] DNS server (through the July 2020 critical vulnerability)

The overall botnet attack was Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others) and caused significant packet loss for our clients due to external link saturation. It required an emergency null-route operation on our side to mitigate.

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. From your side, you would be able to observe the attack as a burst of traffic that likely saturated the network adapter of the source device for perhaps 30 seconds. Since the source device is a member of a botnet that is being used for many attacks, you will see many other mysterious bursts of outbound traffic, as well.

### Justification:
The incident describes a **coordinated DDoS botnet attack** that caused **significant packet loss** and required an **emergency null-route operation** to mitigate. Key evidence includes:  
1. **Volumetric DDoS**: The attack was described as "Nx10Gbps in size" with traffic from multiple sources, including the compromised host. This aligns with **volumetric DoS/DDoS** (e.g., UDP flood, SYN flood) as outlined in **CAT3**.  
2. **Botnet Involvement**: The compromised host was part of a **botnet** used for attacks, which is a hallmark of **DDoS** campaigns (e.g., Mirai botnet).  
3. **Impact**: The attack caused **network saturation** and **service disruption**, directly fitting the definition of a **Denial of Service Attack** (CAT3).  

While the description mentions **vulnerable devices** (e.g., routers, servers) and **potential exploits** (e.g., default credentials, outdated software), these are **indicators of the attack vector** rather than the **primary incident**. The **core event** is the **DDoS attack itself**, making **CAT3** the most appropriate category.  

Other categories (e.g., **CAT5** for vulnerability exploitation) are secondary, as they describe **contributing factors** rather than the **main incident**.

An IP address ([IP_ADDRESS_43f72b8354]) under your control appears to have attacked one of our customers as part of a coordinated DDoS botnet. We manually reviewed the captures from this attack and do not believe that your IP address was spoofed, based on the limited number of distinct hosts attacking us, the identicality of many attacking IP addresses to ones we've seen in the past, and the non-random distribution of IP addresses.

- A compromised Xerox-branded device
- Some other compromised standalone device
- A server with an insecure password that was brute-forced, such as through SSH or RDP
- A server running an improperly secured Hadoop installation
- A server running a pre-13.10.3 GitLab instance that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-22205
- A compromised [ORGANIZATION_c7bac46904] DNS server (through the July 2020 critical vulnerability)

The overall botnet attack was Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others) and caused significant packet loss for our clients due to external link saturation. It required an emergency null-route operation on our side to mitigate.

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. From your side, you would be able to observe the attack as a burst of traffic that likely saturated the network adapter of the source device for perhaps 30 seconds. Since the source device is a member of a botnet that is being used for many attacks, you will see many other mysterious bursts of outbound traffic, as well.

response:
### Classification:
**Category:** CAT3: Denial of Service Attack  
**Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **coordinated DDoS botnet attack** that caused **significant packet loss** and required an **emergency null-route operation** to mitigate. The attack leveraged a compromised host to flood a target's network with traffic, saturating external links and disrupting services. While the description mentions potential vulnerabilities in devices (e.g., routers, webhosts), the **primary impact** is the **denial of service** to the victim's network. This aligns with **CAT3**, which specifically addresses **volumetric DoS/DDoS attacks** (e.g., UDP flood, SYN flood, botnet-driven attacks). The focus is on the **availability disruption** caused by the attack, not the exploitation of a specific vulnerability or unauthorized access.  

---

### Rationale:
- **CAT3** is the most fitting because:  
  1. The attack is **volumetric** (10Gbps traffic) and **botnet-driven**, matching the examples in CAT3 (e.g., "botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server").  
  2. The **primary goal** was to **disrupt availability** (packet loss, link saturation), which is the core definition of a Denial of Service attack.  
  3. While vulnerabilities in devices (e.g., routers, Drupal, GitLab) are mentioned, they are **contextual** (indicating how the botnet was formed) rather than the **primary incident**.  
  4. Other categories (e.g., CAT5 for vulnerability exploitation) are secondary, as the incident is not about exploiting a specific CVE but about the **impact of the attack**.  

**Conclusion:** The incident is best categorized under **CAT3** due to its focus on the **DDoS attack's impact** on availability.

Other categories (e.g., CAT5 for vulnerabilities) are secondary factors, as the **primary classification** hinges on the **attack's effect** (service disruption) rather than the exploitation method.

### Classification:
**Category:** CAT3: Denial of Service Attack  
**Explanation:** The incident involves a **coordinated DDoS botnet attack** that caused significant packet loss and required emergency mitigation (e.g., null-route operations). The attack leverages a network of compromised devices to overwhelm target systems with traffic, aligning with **volumetric DoS/DDoS** (UDP flood, SYN flood, or HTTP/HTTPS traffic). While the description mentions potential vulnerabilities in compromised devices (e.g., default credentials, outdated software), the **primary threat is the denial of service** caused by the botnet's traffic. This falls under **CAT3**, as the core issue is the disruption of service via distributed attack vectors.  

---

### Step-by-Step Justification:
1. **Identify the Core Incident:**  
   The primary event is a **DDoS attack** (e.g., "Nx10Gbps in size" causing "packet loss" and requiring mitigation). The description explicitly labels it as a "coordinated DDoS botnet" attack.  

2. **Compare to NIST Categories:**  
   - **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack):** Directly matches the DDoS attack's goal (disrupting services via traffic overload).  
   - **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation):** While compromised devices (e.g., routers, DNS servers) are listed as potential sources, these are **vulnerabilities exploited** to enable the attack, not the attack itself.  
   - **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt):** The attack is confirmed (via mitigation actions), so it is not "unconfirmed."  

3. **Exclude Other Categories:**  
   - **CAT2 (Malware):** No malware is explicitly mentioned.  
   - **CAT4 (Data Leak):** No data disclosure is described.  
   - **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources):** The attack is malicious, not resource misuse for benign purposes.  

4. **Final Decision:**  
   The **DDoS attack** is the central event, and **CAT3** is the most appropriate category. The mention of compromised devices is contextual (potential attack vectors) but does not override the primary classification.  

--- 

### Summary:  
**CAT3** is selected because the incident is a **volumetric DDoS attack** that disrupted services, which is the defining characteristic of this category. The other details about compromised devices are part of the attack's infrastructure but do not change the primary classification.

### Classification:
**Category:** CAT3: Denial of Service Attack  
**Explanation:** The incident involves a **coordinated DDoS botnet attack** that caused significant packet loss and required emergency mitigation (e.g., null-route operations). The attack leverages a network of compromised devices to overwhelm target systems with traffic, aligning with **volumetric DoS/DDoS** (UDP flood, SYN flood, or HTTP/HTTPS traffic). While the description mentions potential vulnerabilities in compromised devices (e.g., default credentials, outdated software), the **primary threat is the denial of service** caused by the botnet's traffic. This falls under **CAT3**, as the core issue is the disruption of service via distributed attack vectors.  

---

### Step-by-Step Justification:
1. **Identify the Core Incident:**  
   The primary event is a **DDoS attack** (e.g., "Nx10Gbps in size" causing "packet loss" and requiring mitigation). The description explicitly labels it as a "coordinated DDoS botnet" attack.  

2. **Compare to NIST Categories:**  
   - **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack):** Directly matches the DDoS attack's goal (disrupting services via traffic overload).  
   - **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation):** While compromised devices (e.g., routers, DNS servers) are listed as potential sources, these are **vulnerabilities exploited** to enable the attack, not the attack itself.  
   - **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt):** The attack is confirmed (via mitigation actions), so it is not "unconfirmed."  

3. **Exclude Other Categories:**  
   - **CAT2 (Malware):** No malware is explicitly mentioned.  
   - **CAT4 (Data Leak):** No data disclosure is described.  
   - **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources):** The attack is malicious, not resource misuse for benign purposes.  

4. **Final Decision:**  
   The **DDoS attack** is the central event, and **CAT3** is the most appropriate category. The mention of compromised devices is contextual (potential attack vectors) but does not override the primary classification.  

--- 

### Summary:  
**CAT3** is selected because the incident is a **volumetric DDoS attack** that disrupted services, which is the defining characteristic of this category. The other details about compromised devices are part of the attack's infrastructure but do not change the primary classification. The category is: CAT3 
        If classification is not possible, return:
        Category: Unknown

        Explanation: [Justification for the chosen category]

While the description highlights vulnerabilities in compromised devices (e.g., default credentials, outdated software), these are **attack vectors** enabling the DDoS, not the attack itself. The **core threat** is the denial of service caused by the botnet's traffic, making **CAT3** the most appropriate category.

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos de
rede com o serviço SSDP/UPnP habilitado, como roteadores e CPEs (modem
ou roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o serviço SSDP/UPnP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
 equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SSDP/UPnP habilitado, por favor repasse
essa mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* msearch: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e
   pacotes/bytes indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em
   pacotes/bytes;

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_bac286073d]    | 2716   | OPEN   | 2022-11-10T11:54:33Z | msearch: open/1/245
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SSDP/UPnP (1900/udp)?

O SSDP (Simple Service Discovery Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado, em uma rede local, para descoberta de dispositivos Plug
  and Play rodando o protocolo UPnP (Universal Plug and Play).

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SSDP/UPnP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a
  requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O servirço SSDP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SSDP/UPnP nao for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no
  seu dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SSDP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SSDP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS). O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo através do seguinte comando:
  (preferencialmente execute-o a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ printf "M-SEARCH * HTTP/1.1\r\nHost:[IP_ADDRESS_dc765a2247]:1900\r\nST:upnp:rootdevice\r\nMan:\"ssdp:discover\"\r\nMX:3\r\n\r\n" | nc
 -u IP_SSDP 1900

Onde IP_SSDP é o IP do dispositivo usando SSDP a ser testado.
  Antes de exe]

response:
### **Classification:**  
**Category:** CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  

---

### **Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **technical flaw** (misconfigured SSDP/UPnP service) that can be exploited for **amplification-based DDoS attacks**. While the email warns of the potential for DDoS (CAT3), the core issue is the **exploitation of a vulnerability** (SSDP/UPnP misconfiguration) that enables attackers to amplify traffic and overwhelm networks.  

- **Key Points:**  
  1. **Technical Flaw:** The SSDP/UPnP service is accessible via UDP, allowing attackers to exploit it for **amplification attacks** (e.g., UDP-based DDoS).  
  2. **Exploitation Risk:** The notification highlights the **potential for misuse** (e.g., botnets) rather than an active attack. This aligns with **CAT5**, which focuses on **exploiting technical flaws** (e.g., critical CVEs, RCE, or misconfigurations).  
  3. **No Active Attack:** The incident is a **proactive warning** about a vulnerability, not an ongoing attack. This rules out **CAT3** (Denial of Service Attack), which applies to actual attacks.  

- **Why Not CAT3?**  
  While DDoS is a possible outcome, the email does not describe an active attack. Instead, it emphasizes the **risk of exploitation** due to a misconfigured service, which is a **vulnerability** rather than an ongoing attack.  

- **Why Not CAT12?**  
  **CAT12** (Intrusion Attempt) applies to unconfirmed attacks (e.g., network scans). Here, the issue is a **known vulnerability** being exploited, not an unconfirmed attempt.  

---

### **Conclusion:**  
The incident falls under **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)** because it highlights the **misconfiguration of a service** (SSDP/UPnP) that could be exploited for DDoS attacks. The focus is on the **technical flaw** and its potential misuse, not an active attack.

Explanation: The incident involves the exploitation of a technical flaw (SSDP/UPnP service exposed to the internet) that can be leveraged for DDoS attacks. The vulnerability allows amplification attacks by exploiting the protocol's design, which falls under "Vulnerability Exploitation" (CAT5). The CERT.br notification highlights the potential for abuse of this flaw, emphasizing the technical weakness rather than an active attack or malware. This aligns with CAT5's focus on using critical vulnerabilities for attacks, such as UDP-based amplification, which is a known method in DDoS scenarios.

prompt:
You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_9b11a6f892] 10:16 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: Nov 10, 2022 10:16 AM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SSDP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o serviço SSDP/uPnP (1900/udp) habilitado. Este
serviço pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de
negação de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando
terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos de
rede com o serviço SSDP/UPnP habilitado, como roteadores e CPEs (modem
ou roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o serviço SSDP/UPnP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
 equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SSDP/UPnP habilitado, por favor repasse
essa mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* msearch: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e
   pacotes/bytes indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em
   pacotes/bytes;

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_bac286073d]    | 2716   | OPEN   | 2022-11-10T11:54:33Z | msearch: open/1/245
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SSDP/UPnP (1900/udp)?

O SSDP (Simple Service Discovery Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado, em uma rede local, para descoberta de dispositivos Plug
  and Play rodando o protocolo UPnP (Universal Plug and Play).

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SSDP/UPnP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a
  requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O servirço SSDP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SSDP/UPnP nao for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no
  seu dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SSDP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SSDP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS). O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo através do seguinte comando:
  (preferencialmente execute-o a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ printf "M-SEARCH * HTTP/1.1\r\nHost:[IP_ADDRESS_dc765a2247]:1900\r\nST:upnp:rootdevice\r\nMan:\"ssdp:discover\"\r\nMX:3\r\n\r\n" | nc
 -u IP_SSDP 1900

Onde IP_SSDP é o IP do dispositivo usando SSDP a ser testado.
  Antes de exe]
            ```
        
        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

        Your task:
        - Classify the incident below using the most appropriate category code (CAT1 to CAT12).
        - Justify based on the explanation of the selected category.
         

### **Classification:**  
**Category:** CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)  

---

### **Explanation:**  
The incident involves a **technical flaw** (misconfigured SSDP/UPnP service) that can be exploited for **amplification-based DDoS attacks**. While the email warns of the potential for DDoS (CAT3), the core issue is the **exploitation of a vulnerability** (SSDP/UPnP misconfiguration) that enables attackers to amplify traffic and overwhelm networks.  

- **Key Points:**  
  1. **Technical Flaw:** The SSDP/UPnP service is accessible via UDP, allowing attackers to exploit it for **amplification attacks** (e.g., UDP-based DDoS).  
  2. **Exploitation Risk:** The notification highlights the **potential for misuse** (e.g., botnets) rather than an active attack. This aligns with **CAT5**, which focuses on **exploiting technical flaws** (e.g., critical CVEs, RCE, or misconfigurations).  
  3. **No Active Attack:** The incident is a **proactive warning** about a vulnerability, not an ongoing attack. This rules out **CAT3** (Denial of Service Attack), which applies to actual attacks.  

- **Why Not CAT3?**  
  While DDoS is a possible outcome, the email does not describe an active attack. Instead, it emphasizes the **risk of exploitation** due to a misconfigured service, which is a **vulnerability** rather than an ongoing attack.  

- **Why Not CAT12?**  
  **CAT12** (Intrusion Attempt) applies to unconfirmed attacks (e.g., network scans). Here, the issue is a **known vulnerability** being exploited, not an unconfirmed attempt.  

---

### **Conclusion:**  
The incident falls under **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)** because it highlights the **misconfiguration of a service** (SSDP/UPnP) that could be exploited for DDoS attacks. The focus is on the **technical flaw** and its potential misuse, not an active attack. The category is: CAT5 
        If classification is not possible, return:
        Category: Unknown
        Explanation: Unknown
        
        OUTPUT:
        Category: [NIST code]
        Explanation: [Justification for the chosen category]

response:
### **Classification:**
**Category:** CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)  
**Explanation:**  

The incident involves **misconfigured NTP servers** that could be exploited to participate in **distributed denial-of-service (DDoS)** attacks. These servers are vulnerable to **amplification attacks** (e.g., via `monlist` or `readvar` commands), which allow attackers to generate massive traffic volumes by exploiting the servers’ responses. This creates a **volumetric DDoS risk**, as the servers could be used to overwhelm targets with traffic, rendering systems unavailable.  

The **NIST category CAT3** explicitly includes:  
- *Volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP/HTTPS)*  
- *Attack on publicly available APIs or websites*  
- *Botnet Mirai attacking an institution’s server*  

The notification from CERT.br highlights the **potential for these servers to be abused in DDoS attacks**, which aligns directly with **CAT3**. While the misconfiguration itself is a technical flaw (potentially falling under **CAT5**), the **primary risk described is the potential for a DDoS attack**, making **CAT3** the most appropriate category.  

**Key Justification:**  
- The incident is a **security risk** tied to **DDoS amplification** via misconfigured NTP servers.  
- The **core issue** is the **potential for systems to be made unavailable** due to misuse of the servers.  
- The **notification emphasizes proactive mitigation** of a threat that could enable **volumetric DDoS attacks**, fitting **CAT3**.  

**Alternative Consideration:**  
If the focus were solely on the **vulnerability** (e.g., a technical flaw in the NTP configuration), **CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation)** could apply. However, the **primary concern here is the potential for an attack** (DDoS), not the vulnerability itself. Thus, **CAT3** is more precise.

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre configuração segura de
  servidores NTP?
